items.content_html: Another SwiftoDo update will come at the end of next week, as long as I can get the timing right with App Store review. I cannot promise weekly updates forever, but right now I am trying to release the best version possible to my users, as soon as possible.

SwiftoDo 2.8.0 is now available in the App Store. It adds a picker to make adding recurrence pattern tags (for daily, weekly, monthly, etc.) to tasks easier. It also lets you drop tasks onto the task list from other apps (iPad only).

I am listening to music from my MacBook Pro today, via the Oppo HA-2SE. One benefit is that it charges through its micro USB input, so playtime is unlimited. iTunes is slower and buggier than the iOS Music app, though.

Adding my Nest thermostat to HomeKit via HomeBridge has made my life a little better. I do have a suggestion for Apple, though: ‚ÄúHey Siri, set thermostat to 70¬∫ F and let no one in my family change it, ever, for any reason.‚Äù Maybe I don‚Äôt need a smart thermostat after all.

I downloaded Visual Studio Code on my Windows work machine today. I don‚Äôt see how it will be better than Sublime Text for me however. I mostly need speed and some extensibility, and don‚Äôt need to compile or debug so much.
My wife baked a delicious Valentine‚Äôs Day treat. ‚ù§Ô∏èüòÑ
Blog post: My Slide into Audiophile Territory, Part 1

Tonight I set up HomeBridge on an otherwise unused Raspberry Pi to control my Nest thermostat via Siri and HomeKit. The hardest part for me was getting it set up as a service, because I hadn‚Äôt used systemd before. I blame/thank FreeBSD for that!
If Apple really is slowing down and fixing bugs, rather than adding features, I wish they would work more on Xcode 9, which is still a mess for me for Swift development.
I‚Äôm coding a user-requested feature this evening. I started really late after a 2-hour trip to Wegmans. I stayed up to do a particularly satisfying refactor.
